TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: 82 yo with a hx of DM, CAD s/p CABG [**2152**] redo [**10/2171**]
   (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM, SVG-Diag), CHF (EF 51%), and EtOH abuse, admitted to
   OSH for shortness of breath and chest pain and transferred to the [**Hospital1 19**]
   for cardiac catheterization that was aborted [**1-29**] delirium and agitation
   on [**1-22**] until [**1-25**]: Promus LIMA to LAD, on RHC.
   24 Hour Events:
   [**2-5**]
   -Patient conversant, knows he is in [**Hospital 23**] Hospital in [**2182-1-28**].
   Patient angry about restraints and attention from RNs.  Mental status
   markedly improved.
   [**2-4**]
   - Refusing POs after olanzapine ; given lower dose (22 u ) NPH and no
   humalog for bld gluc 121 this AM
   - started standing low dose seroquel at 7pm, per [**Female First Name (un) **]; will increase
   dose if needed
   - re-consulted Geriatrics for delirium --> seroquel QHS, and consider
   starting Neurontin low dose tomorrow night (pt was on neurontin at home
   previously, stopped end of [**Month (only) **] for some reason)
   - bradycardia down to 30s w junctional rhythm, then HR back to 80s
   - febrile, blood and urine cultures, stat CXR
   - transferred back to CCU
   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of
   metabolic alkalosis; clinically respiratory status looks improved,
   breathing ~28/min (rather than >40)
   - ABG 4:30pm showed improved pCO2
   - given nighttime olanzapine ~9pm (had started becoming awake/agitated
   again around 8am but not too agitated)-- (didnt use seroquel as planned
   b/c he didnt seem like he could swallow reliably); gave him the
   antipsychotic to help him rest --> appeared to work for a while, but
   nursing thought it was just because he tired himself out...
   - 3am pt became more agitated kicking around, trying to get out of bed
   to go to work; nurse didnt feel zyprexa would work anyway; couldnt get
   an ekg to check QT either b/c pt so agitated; put him on leg restraints
   (only while nurse was in room w him)
   - 5:30am screaming out for help constantly ; gave 2.5mg olanzapine 6am;
   will need ekg when calm
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below

   Troponin-T:38/3/0.11, ALT / AST:29/42, Alk Phos / T Bili:75/0.9,
   Amylase / Lipase:/10, Lactic Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Ca++:9.3 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8
   mg/dL, PO4:2.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for cardiac
   catheterization after ICU admission for respiratory failure during
   which time he had an elevated Troponin and was intubated for hypoxic
   respiratory failure and DTs.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Currently, patient has a new
   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting
   catheterization on [**1-24**] for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA
   occlusion. Currently, he is chest pain free, but refusing EKG.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Plavix 75mg daily
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Heparin gtt
   - No Integrillin given current Troponin
   .
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**]. Patient with persistent fluid overload
   on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac
   catheterization. On transfer, patient demonstrates mild respiratory
   distress and O2 requirement, limited clinical exam suggests fluid
   overload.
   - Lasix 40mg IV x 1, repeat PRN
   - O2 by NC
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Lisinopril 2.5mg daily
   .
   # Agitation/Mental status changes: Patient's cardiac catheterization
   aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to significant doses of
   Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital records, patient has
   been confused and agitated since his hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. He
   pulled out his Foley prior to transfer to the [**Hospital1 19**] and his wife
   reports that he was paranoid at [**Location (un) 755**], insisting that the FBI was out
   to get him. At home, however, his wife states that he is not confused,
   but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As patient has been
   attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is not fully
   oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary process
   appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium.
   Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may have some component
   of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - Psych consult, recommending 0.5 to 1mg q4H:PRN agitation
   - Will try to avoid Haldol/Zyprexa as it will further prolong QT
   interval
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes
   - Preserve sleep wake cycles
   - OOB for meals
   .
   #. Rhythm: Patient in and out of AF in the CCU, but no report of h/o of
   AF. He has also been persistently tachycardic, despite having a regular
   rhythm on admission. This may be agitation paired with diuresis, but
   will continue to monitor closely.
   - On telemetry
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg PO BID
   .
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   - Gabapentin 600mg PO qHS
   .
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN
   - SW consult
   .
   #. HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   .
   #. HTN:
   -Continue Lisinopril 2.5mg daily
   -Continue Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg PO BID
   .
   #. GERD:
   - Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   .
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe
   .
   #. Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved. No
   focal neurologic deficits on admission.
   .
   #. FEN: Cardiac/diabetic, MVI
   .
   #. Access: PIV, right subclavian line (will plan to d/c when patient
   cooperative)
   .
   #. PPx: Heparin gtt
   .
   #. Communication: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2064**] [**Known lastname 12865**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12866**]
   .
   #. Code: FULL
   .
   #. Dispo: pending repeat cardiac catheterization
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2182-2-4**] 12:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes, chronic heart failure (CHF), and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with shortness of breath and chest pain, and was later transferred to another hospital for cardiac catheterization. The catheterization was aborted due to the patient's agitation and delirium.

The patient has been experiencing agitation and delirium since admission, which has been refractory to treatment with Haldol. He has also been experiencing tachycardia and hypertension, and has been treated with metoprolol and lasix.

The patient's cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, and he has been placed on a new stent in the SVG-OM1. He is awaiting repeat cardiac catheterization to evaluate and treat the LIMA occlusion.

The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, with periods of agitation and confusion. He has been taking Ativan PO PRN at home, which may be contributing to his agitation and delirium.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, which are consistent with cardiac injury. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 98 beats per minute.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Delirium: The patient's delirium is a significant concern, as it can lead to further complications such as falls, respiratory depression, and increased mortality.
3. Agitation: The patient's agitation is a significant concern, as it can lead to further complications such as increased heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a significant concern, as it can lead to further complications such as cardiac complications, kidney damage, and stroke.
5. Respiratory complications: The patient's tachypnea and oxygen requirement are a significant concern, as they can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count are a significant concern, as they can lead to further complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, and consider repeat cardiac catheterization to evaluate and treat the LIMA occlusion.
2. Continue to manage the patient's delirium and agitation with medication and non-pharmacological interventions.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider adjusting his antihypertensive medications as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, and consider adjusting his oxygen therapy as necessary.
5. Consider starting the patient on antibiotics to cover potential infections.
6. Consider starting the patient on anticoagulation therapy to prevent further cardiac complications.

   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of

Chief Complaint: 82M with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for
   cardiac catheterization s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.
   24 Hour Events:
   - started low dose seroquel at 7pm per [**Female First Name (un) **]
   - re-consulted Geriatrics for delirium --> seroquel QHS, and consider
   starting Neurontin low dose tomorrow night (pt was on neurontin at home
   previously, stopped end of [**Month (only) **] for some reason)
   - bradycardia down to 30s w junctional rhythm, then HR back to 80s -
   possible vagal, ?aspiration
   - febrile, blood and urine cultures, stat CXR
   - transferred back to CCU
   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of
   metabolic alkalosis; clinically respiratory status looks improved,
   breathing ~28/min (rather than >40)
   - given nighttime olanzapine ~9pm (had started becoming awake/agitated
   again around 8am but not too agitated)-- (didnt use seroquel as planned
   b/c he didnt seem like he could swallow reliably); gave him the
   antipsychotic to help him rest --> appeared to work for a while, but
   nursing thought it was just because he tired himself out.
   - 3am pt became more agitated kicking around, trying to get out of bed
   to go to work; nurse didnt feel zyprexa would work anyway; couldnt get
   an ekg to check QT either b/c pt so agitated; put him on leg restraints
   (only while nurse was in room w him)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse, who was transferred to the hospital for cardiac catheterization after experiencing symptoms of unstable angina and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving oxygen therapy to maintain a SaO2 of >92%.
2. Agitation: The patient has been agitated since admission and has required restraints and chemical restraints to manage his behavior.
3. Delirium: The patient has been diagnosed with delirium and is being treated with seroquel and neurontin.
4. Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate has been documented as being in the 30s and 40s, with a possible vagal or aspiration-related etiology.
5. Fever: The patient has a fever, and blood and urine cultures have been sent to rule out infection.
6. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has a pH of 7.43, paCO2 of 55, and paO2 of 75, which is consistent with respiratory acidosis.
7. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is 121/67 mmHg.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose is 136 mg/dL.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is 4.3 mEq/L, sodium level is 136 mg/dL, and chloride level is 103 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) are potential complications.
2. Agitation: Seizures, aspiration pneumonia, and increased risk of falls are potential complications.
3. Delirium: Increased risk of falls, aspiration pneumonia, and prolonged hospital stay are potential complications.
4. Bradycardia: Bradycardia can lead to cardiac arrest, and the patient's underlying cardiac condition may increase the risk of cardiac complications.
5. Fever: Sepsis, bacteremia, and pneumonia are potential complications.
6. Metabolic alkalosis: Respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures are potential complications.
7. Hypertension: Cardiac complications, such as heart failure and myocardial infarction, are potential complications.
8. Hyperglycemia: Diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma, and increased risk of infections are potential complications.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: Cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and seizures are potential complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued respiratory support with oxygen therapy.
2. Agitation management with seroquel and neurontin.
3. Delirium management with seroquel and neurontin.
4. Bradycardia management with atropine and pacing.
5. Fever management with antibiotics and antipyretics.
6. Metabolic alkalosis management with sodium bicarbonate and diuresis.
7. Hypertension management with antihypertensive medications.
8. Hyperglycemia management with insulin sliding scale.
9. Electrolyte imbalance management with electrolyte replacement therapy.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after being intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation. He has a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse. The patient has been experiencing agitation and mental status changes since admission, which has required restraints and chemical restraints. He has also been experiencing bradycardia and has been treated with low-dose seroquel and olanzapine.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 38 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 94%. His cardiac rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient's lab results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible NSTEMI/CAD. His cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He has also been diagnosed with acute on chronic systolic CHF, and has been diuresed.

The patient's medication regimen includes aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol tartrate, and lisinopril. He is also receiving insulin sliding scale and NPH insulin for his DM.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest possible NSTEMI/CAD, which can lead to further cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and death.
2. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient's CHF can worsen with further fluid overload, leading to respiratory failure and death.
3. Agitation and mental status changes: The patient's agitation and mental status changes can lead to further complications such as falls, injuries, and increased risk of infection.
4. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia can lead to further complications such as heart block, arrhythmias, and death.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen with further fluid overload, leading to respiratory arrest and death.
6. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines and tubes can increase his risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis and death.
7. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulant medications and presence of central lines and tubes can increase his risk of bleeding, which can lead to further complications such as hypovolemic shock and death.
8. Renal failure: The patient's CHF and use of diuretics can increase his risk of renal failure, which can worsen his condition and lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and death.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's DM and use of insulin can increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to eat and his use of insulin can increase his risk of nutritional deficiencies such as malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies, which can worsen his condition and lead to further complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. He has a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, and he was treated with DES to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, with an ABG showing pH 7.43, paCO2 55, and paO2 75. He is diuresing well and has been given a dose of IV acetazolamide for metabolic alkalosis.

The patient has been experiencing agitation and has required restraints and chemical restraints. He has been started on zyprexa and is being considered for a psych consult.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still be at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and the presence of pleural effusion.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Neurological complications: The patient has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli, which may lead to neurological complications such as stroke or seizures.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is at risk for infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Delirium: The patient has been experiencing agitation and may be at risk for delirium, particularly with the use of sedatives and analgesics.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal disease and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Hematological complications: The patient has a history of bleeding and may be at risk for hematological complications such as bleeding or anemia.
8. Renal complications: The patient has a history of kidney disease and may be at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication as needed.
3. Consider a psych consult to evaluate the patient's agitation and delirium.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medication as needed.
6. Consider a gastrointestinal consult to evaluate the patient's risk for gastrointestinal complications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hematological status and adjust his medication as needed.
8. Consider a hematological consult to evaluate the patient's risk for hematological complications.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust his medication as needed.
10. Consider a nephrology consult to evaluate the patient's risk for renal complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and was found to have altered mental status, likely due to delirium. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3C, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 104/57 mmHg. He is on mechanical ventilation and has a SpO2 of 97%. His laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated troponin levels, and elevated liver enzymes.

The patient's medications include:

* Torsemide 20mg daily
* Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
* Lisinopril 2.5mg daily
* Heparin sodium 5000 units SQ every 12 hours
* Aspirin 325mg daily
* Plavix 75mg daily
* Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* NPH insulin 22u daily
* Humalog sliding scale

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Hypotension due to diuretic use
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or aspiration
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalance
* Sepsis due to cellulitis on the left anterior lower leg
* Delirium due to medication or underlying medical condition
* Pulmonary embolism due to immobility

Based on the patient's progress note, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely
* Adjust the patient's medications as needed to manage his symptoms and prevent complications
* Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen if the cellulitis on the left anterior lower leg is not improving
* Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy as needed to manage the patient's respiratory status
* Consider consulting with a pulmonologist or intensivist to further manage the patient's respiratory status
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medications as needed to manage his delirium.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and intubation due to hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient has been experiencing altered mental status/delirium since admission, with multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli. He has required restraints and chemical restraints intermittently and has responded to seroquel for a couple of hours last night. He has also been started on low-dose neurontin and frequent reorientation.

The patient has acute on chronic systolic CHF, which was apparent when he appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. He has been diuresed, and lasix was discontinued yesterday. Torsemide was decreased to 20mg daily due to hypotensive episode.

The patient has a history of NSTEMI/CAD, with symptoms prior to hospitalization concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at the outside hospital suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of troponin elevation. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts, but the patient's agitation during the procedure prevented completion of the catheterization. He has been treated with aspirin, plavix, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and low-dose acei.

The patient also has a history of DM, ethanol abuse, hypertension (HTN), and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). He has been treated with NPH and insulin sliding scale, gabapentin, ranitidine, and metoprolol.

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued agitation and delirium: The patient's agitation and delirium may persist, requiring continued use of restraints and chemical restraints, and frequent reorientation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotensive episode yesterday may recur, requiring continued monitoring of blood pressure and potential adjustments to medications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may persist, requiring continued oxygen therapy and close monitoring of respiratory status.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and ongoing CHF may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
5. Worsening kidney function: The patient's ongoing diuresis and potential use of nephrotoxic medications may worsen his kidney function, requiring close monitoring of laboratory values and potential adjustments to medications.
6. Infections: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and ongoing use of central lines and tubes may increase the risk of infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of GERD and ongoing use of ranitidine may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding and perforation.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation.

The patient's mental status has been altered, with alternating hypoactive and hyperactive delirium. He has required restraints and chemical restraints to prevent injury to himself and others. The patient has responded to seroquel for a couple of hours last night, but has also been somnolent in the middle of the day intermittently.

The patient has acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. He has been diuresed and has had multiple ABGs drawn for concern of somnolence and hypercarbia. The patient's urine output and mental status may correlate with blood pressure.

The patient has a history of NSTEMI/CAD, with symptoms prior to hospitalization concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at the outside hospital suggestive of NSTEMI. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts, but the patient's agitation during the procedure prevented completion of the catheterization.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 6.2-8.7 K/uL
* Hct: 29.9-33.8%
* Plt: 161-275 K/uL
* Cr: 1.0-1.3 mg/dL
* TCO2: 33-40 mmHg
* Glucose: 125-256 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.9/29.4/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/3/0.11, ALT/AST: 29/42, Alk Phos/T Bili: 75/0.9, Amylase/Lipase: 10, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Further deterioration of mental status due to delirium
* Development of respiratory failure or worsening of hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias or worsening of systolic heart failure
* Development of sepsis or other infections
* Worsening of diabetes mellitus
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to stress ulcer
* Development of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and DVT prophylaxis
* Development of anxiety or depression

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue seroquel at night and add prn Haldol TID
* DCed neurontin
* Frequent reorientation
* Minimize lines and tubes as possible
* Sleep-wake cycles
* OOB for meals as possible
* Continue 20mg torsemide daily
* Oxygen for SaO2 > 92%
* Continue Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
* DCed lisinopril
* Continue aspirin 325mg
* Continue Plavix
* Continue atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Continue NPH 22u daily and Humalog sliding scale
* Monitor for EtOH withdrawal
* SW consult
* Continue ranitidine 150mg PO BID
* Continue to observe for anxiety/depression

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care.

   .

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, elevated Troponin, and DTs. He underwent cardiac catheterization and was intubated. The patient's condition has improved, but he is still experiencing delirium and agitation. He has a history of NSTEMI, CAD, and CHF with EF 51%. He is currently receiving medications for CHF, CAD, and DM.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued agitation and delirium: The patient's delirium and agitation may persist, leading to increased risk of falls, skin breakdown, and respiratory complications.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI, CAD, and CHF puts him at risk for future cardiovascular events, such as MI, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's history of respiratory failure and continued intubation increases his risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and tracheal stenosis.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of etoh abuse and DM increases his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis, gastritis, and malnutrition.
5. Infections: The patient's history of cellulitis and DTs puts him at risk for future infections, such as sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's history of DM and etoh abuse increases his risk for nutritional deficiencies, such as malnutrition, vitamin deficiencies, and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Medication interactions: The patient's polypharmacy increases his risk for medication interactions, such as adverse reactions, interactions with other medications, and decreased efficacy of medications.
8. Psychological complications: The patient's history of etoh abuse and delirium increases his risk for psychological complications, such as depression, anxiety, and cognitive impairment.
9. Skin breakdown: The patient's history of cellulitis and etoh abuse increases his risk for skin breakdown, such as pressure ulcers, decubitus ulcers, and skin tears.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's history of TIA and DM increases his risk for neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and elevated Troponin, and was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and delirium.

The patient has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD for 95% stenoses. He has also been diagnosed with acute on chronic systolic heart failure, persistent pulmonary edema, and delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Hypotensive episodes due to excessive vasodilation or cardiac depression
	* Bradycardia or tachycardia due to medication or electrolyte imbalance
	* Atrial fibrillation or flutter due to cardiac stress or electrolyte imbalance
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia or respiratory failure due to prolonged intubation and ventilation
	* Respiratory distress due to pulmonary edema or pleural effusion
3. Neurological complications:
	* Delirium or agitation due to medication, electrolyte imbalance, or sepsis
	* Cerebral edema or intracranial hemorrhage due to hypoxia or hypertension
4. Infectious complications:
	* Cellulitis or sepsis due to skin or soft tissue infection
	* Urinary tract infection or pneumonia due to indwelling catheter or ventilation
5. Metabolic complications:
	* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia due to insulin regimen or medication
	* Electrolyte imbalance due to medication, kidney function, or acid-base status
6. Hematological complications:
	* Bleeding or thrombocytopenia due to anticoagulation or platelet dysfunction
	* Anemia or thrombocytopenia due to blood loss or bone marrow suppression

To mitigate these risks, the patient is being monitored closely, and various medications and treatments are being implemented to manage his conditions. These include:

* Torsemide to manage heart failure and pulmonary edema
* Quetiapine and haldol to manage delirium and agitation
* Cephalexin to treat cellulitis
* Aspirin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel to prevent cardiovascular events
* Metoprolol to manage heart rate and blood pressure
* Insulin and NPH to manage blood glucose levels
* Heparin to prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

The patient's condition will continue to be closely monitored, and adjustments to his treatment plan will be made as needed to manage his symptoms and prevent complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications and concerns have arisen:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* The patient has a history of CABG, NSTEMI, and CAD, which increases the risk of cardiac complications. The patient's Troponin levels have been elevated, and they have undergone PCI with stenting.
	* The patient has been experiencing hypotension and tachycardia, which may be related to the cardiac condition.
	* The patient has been prescribed ASA, atorvastatin, and plavix to manage their cardiac condition.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* The patient has a history of respiratory failure and has been intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
	* The patient has been experiencing mild labored breathing and posterior lung exam crackles, which may indicate ongoing respiratory issues.
3. Neurological Complications:
	* The patient has been experiencing agitation, delirium, and sun-downing, which may be related to the cardiac condition or underlying neurological issues.
	* The patient has been prescribed quetiapine to manage their agitation and delirium.
4. Endocrine Complications:
	* The patient has a history of DM and has been prescribed NPH and insulin sliding scale to manage their blood sugar levels.
5. Renal Complications:
	* The patient's creatinine levels have been elevated, which may indicate underlying kidney damage or dysfunction.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* The patient has been experiencing gastrointestinal issues, including nausea and vomiting, which may be related to their cardiac condition or underlying gastrointestinal issues.
7. Infectious Complications:
	* The patient has been prescribed antibiotics for suspected infections, and their UA has been pending.
8. Other Complications:
	* The patient has a history of etoh abuse and has been experiencing DTs.
	* The patient has been prescribed lorazepam for anxiety and has been advised to continue with folate and thiamine.

Based on the patient's progress note, it appears that they are at risk for further complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, and neurological decline. It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting their treatment plan as needed to prevent further complications and improve their overall outcome.

   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for

   .

   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes, and ethanol abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and elevated troponin levels. He was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and delirium/tremors (DTs). The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD for 95% stenoses. He has been experiencing symptoms of NSTEMI/CAD, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and agitation/mental status changes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina, and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation.
	* Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient has persistent pulmonary edema following NSTEMI and PCI, which may lead to further cardiac complications.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure, which may lead to further respiratory complications.
3. Neurological Complications:
	* Agitation/mental status changes: The patient has been experiencing delirium/sun-downing, which may lead to further neurological complications.
	* DVT: The patient has a history of TIA, which may increase the risk of DVT.
4. Infection Complications:
	* UTI: The patient's UA was positive for bacteria, which may indicate a UTI.
	* VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to his prolonged intubation.
5. Medication Complications:
	* Metoprolol: The patient is taking metoprolol, which may interact with other medications and increase the risk of adverse effects.
	* Lisinopril: The patient is taking lisinopril, which may increase the risk of angioedema and hyperkalemia.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust medications as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust antibiotics as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's medication regimen and adjust as necessary to minimize adverse effects.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and delirium. The patient underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have 95% stenosis in the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD, which was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting.

The patient's current condition is marked by agitation, delirium, and sun-downing, which is being managed with sedation and psychotropic medications. He has a history of NSTEMI/CAD, acute on chronic systolic heart failure, and is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias. The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and current electrolyte abnormalities put him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.
2. Worsening heart failure: The patient's acute on chronic systolic heart failure may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to increased pulmonary edema and decreased cardiac output.
3. Delirium and agitation: The patient's current delirium and agitation may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to increased risk of falls, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia may worsen if not corrected, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Infection: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and current delirium may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia.
6. Thrombosis: The patient's history of DVT and current anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk of thrombosis, particularly in the setting of cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Renal insufficiency: The patient's history of DM and current electrolyte abnormalities may increase his risk of renal insufficiency, particularly if not managed effectively.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac arrhythmias with antiarrhythmic medications and close monitoring.
2. Optimize the patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus, to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
3. Continue to manage the patient's delirium and agitation with sedation and psychotropic medications, and consider consulting psychiatry for further management.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, particularly in the setting of delirium and agitation.
5. Consider consulting cardiology for further management of the patient's cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function closely, particularly in the setting of electrolyte abnormalities and DM.
7. Consider consulting infectious disease for further management of the patient's potential infections.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse. He was transferred for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts. He developed hypoxemic respiratory failure and was intubated.

Current medical conditions:

1. Altered Mental Status/Delirium: The patient has been agitated since admission and has been diagnosed with delirium. He has responded to seroquel and haldol, and geriatrics is following.
2. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has CHF with an EF of 30-35%. He has been fluid overloaded and has required oxygen therapy.
3. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and his enzymes were suggestive of NSTEMI. He underwent cardiac catheterization, which demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts.
4. DM: The patient has DM and is receiving NPH and insulin sliding scale therapy.
5. EtOH Abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is being monitored for withdrawal.
6. HLD: The patient is receiving atorvastatin therapy for hyperlipidemia.
7. HTN: The patient has hypertension and is being treated with metoprolol tartrate.
8. GERD: The patient has GERD and is receiving ranitidine therapy.
9. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status is stable, and he is being observed.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has cellulitis of the left ankle, which may progress to sepsis if not properly treated.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has bibasilar rales and crackles in his lung fields, which may indicate pneumonia.
3. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and history of cardiac catheterization.
4. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to his intubation and prolonged hospitalization.
5. GI bleeding: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and may be at risk for GI bleeding.
6. Worsening of CHF: The patient's CHF may worsen if not properly managed.
7. Worsening of mental status: The patient's mental status may worsen if not properly managed.

Plan:

1. Continue seroquel and haldol as needed to manage the patient's delirium.
2. Continue fluid management to prevent fluid overload.
3. Continue oxygen therapy to maintain SaO2 > 92%.
4. Continue metoprolol tartrate and atorvastatin therapy as prescribed.
5. Continue NPH and insulin sliding scale therapy as prescribed.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's wound and prevent infection.
8. Continue prophylactic antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy as prescribed.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes, and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the hospital with cardiac catheterization for unstable angina and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He also has a history of systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 30-35%.

The patient's current condition is complex and includes:

1. Altered mental status/delirium: The patient has been agitated since admission and has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli. He has required restraints and chemical restraints to prevent injury to himself and others.
2. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient has been diuresed and has had ABGs drawn multiple times in the past several days for concern of somnolence and hypercarbia. His blood pressure has been unstable, and he has been treated with torsemide and metoprolol tartrate.
3. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina, and his enzymes were suggestive of NSTEMI. He has been treated with aspirin, plavix, and atorvastatin.
4. DM: The patient has been treated with NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital.
5. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is being monitored for withdrawal.
6. HLD: The patient is being treated with atorvastatin 80mg daily.
7. HTN: The patient has been treated with lisinopril 2.5mg daily and metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
8. GERD: The patient has been treated with ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
9. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status is stable, and he is being observed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Worsening of delirium: The patient's altered mental status/delirium can worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased agitation, aggression, and risk of injury to himself or others.
2. Fluid overload: The patient's acute on chronic systolic CHF can lead to fluid overload, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
3. Hypotension: The patient's unstable blood pressure can lead to hypotension, which can worsen his cardiac and cerebral status.
4. Infection: The patient's multiple lines and tubes can increase his risk of infection, particularly VAP and DVT.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of GERD and use of anticoagulant medications can increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of CAD and NSTEMI/CAD can increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, particularly tachycardia and bradycardia.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued use of oxygen therapy can increase his risk of respiratory failure.

In summary, the patient's current condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential medical complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Delirium: The patient's delirium is likely caused by a combination of factors, including hypoxemic respiratory failure, agitation, and potential emboli from the cardiac catheterization procedure. The patient's mental status is altered, and they are experiencing alternating hypoactive and hyperactive delirium.
2. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF with an EF of 30-35%. They are fluid overloaded and have hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is not being fully managed with diuresis due to concerns about blood pressure.
3. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina, and their troponin levels were elevated on admission. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, but the procedure was not completed due to patient agitation.
4. DM: The patient has a history of DM and is being managed with NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital. However, their blood glucose levels are not well-controlled, and they require further monitoring and adjustment of their medication regimen.
5. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and is at risk for withdrawal. They require close monitoring and may require treatment for withdrawal symptoms.
6. HLD: The patient is at risk for hyperlipidemia due to their history of CHF and CAD. They require continued treatment with atorvastatin to manage their lipid levels.
7. HTN: The patient has a history of hypertension and is being managed with metoprolol tartrate. However, their blood pressure is not well-controlled, and they require further monitoring and adjustment of their medication regimen.
8. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and is being managed with ranitidine. However, their symptoms are not well-controlled, and they require further monitoring and adjustment of their medication regimen.
9. Anxiety/Depression: The patient has a history of anxiety and depression, and their symptoms are stable. However, they require continued observation and monitoring to ensure that their mental health is not worsening.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure and is requiring oxygen therapy. They are at risk for further respiratory compromise and require close monitoring and management of their respiratory status.

The patient's medical complications are complex and require close monitoring and management by the healthcare team.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and chronic systolic heart failure (CHF). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) and left internal mammary artery (LIMA) grafts.

The patient's current condition is marked by:

1. Delirium: The patient is experiencing alternating periods of hypoactive and hyperactive delirium, which is likely secondary to his underlying medical conditions, including CHF, DM, and ethanol abuse.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is likely related to his CHF and possible aspiration.
3. Agitation: The patient has been agitated and verbally aggressive towards female nurses, which is likely related to his delirium and underlying medical conditions.
4. Fluid overload: The patient has been fluid overloaded and has required diuresis to manage his CHF.
5. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient has been diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and coronary artery disease (CAD), which is likely related to his CHF and DM.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen, leading to increased agitation, aggression, and potential harm to himself or others.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements, intubation, and potential complications such as pneumonia or respiratory arrest.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD may lead to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and lines may increase his risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis, organ failure, and potential death.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and DM may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications such as pancreatitis, GI bleeding, or malnutrition.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of worsening delirium, respiratory failure, cardiac complications, infection, and gastrointestinal complications. The patient's medications should be carefully titrated to manage his underlying medical conditions, and the ICU team should work closely with the patient's primary care physician to develop a comprehensive plan for his care.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of NSTEMI and delirium. He has a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse. He was transferred from an outside hospital for cardiac catheterization, which was incomplete due to his agitation. He was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued to be agitated, likely due to delirium. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.

Current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 36.2C (97.2F)
* Heart rate: 78-113 bpm
* Blood pressure: 126/72-130/82 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/min
* SpO2: 94%
* WBC: 8.7-5.2 K/uL
* Hct: 33.8-30.7%
* Plt: 174-166 K/uL
* Cr: 1.2-1.3 mg/dL
* TCO2: 38 mmHg
* Glucose: 136-154 mg/dL

The patient is receiving various medications, including:

* Haldol 1mg PO TID for agitation
* Torsemide 20mg daily for fluid balance
* Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID for CHF and hypertension
* Aspirin 325mg for CAD
* Plavix for CAD
* Atorvastatin 80mg daily for HLD
* Ranitidine 150mg PO BID for GERD

Potential medical complications:

* Delirium: The patient's delirium may continue to worsen if not managed properly. He may require more aggressive treatment, such as increased doses of Haldol or the addition of other medications.
* CHF: The patient's CHF may worsen if not managed properly. He may require diuretic therapy or other medications to manage his fluid balance.
* CAD: The patient's CAD may worsen if not managed properly. He may require additional medications or interventions to manage his condition.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his immobility and presence of central venous catheters. He may require prophylactic anticoagulation therapy.
* VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to his intubation and presence of central venous catheters. He may require prophylactic antibiotics and other measures to prevent VAP.
* Sleep-wake cycle disturbances: The patient's sleep-wake cycle may be disturbed due to his delirium and presence of central venous catheters. He may require measures to promote sleep and wakefulness.
* Wound complications: The patient's wounds may become infected or develop complications due to his presence of central venous catheters and other invasive devices. He may require close monitoring and wound care.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse, admitted to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and intubation for hypoxemic respiratory failure. He has been experiencing altered mental status/delirium, which is likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli. He has multiple new lesions in his brain and is currently on restraints. His physical examination reveals right upper sternal border murmur, right and left radial pulse present, but diminished right and left DP pulse. He has trace right and left lower extremity edema and a soft, non-tender abdomen.

The patient's lab results show elevated troponin levels, indicating NSTEMI, and his cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He has been started on aspirin, plavix, and atorvastatin, and his DM is being managed with NPH and insulin sliding scale.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued delirium and agitation: The patient's delirium is likely to continue, and he may require further sedation and reorientation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may continue, and he may require further oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
4. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and potential line infections may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or organ failure.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's new lesions in his brain may lead to further neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's GERD and potential stress ulcer may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Renal complications: The patient's fluid overload and potential AKI may lead to further renal complications, such as chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
8. Psychological complications: The patient's delirium and potential dementia may lead to further psychological complications, such as anxiety or depression.

   82M with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for cardiac
   catheterization s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for hypoxemic
   respiratory failure and continued agitation.
   # Altered Mental Status/ Delirium:
   Alternating Hypoactive and Hyperactive Delirium.  The patient has been
   agitated since the outside hospital, likely delirious since
   presentation from outside hospital. He has multiple new lesions in his
   brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.  Did not require
   four-point restraints last night.  Given increased 100mg dose of
   seroquel, .  Haldol may be more effective than seroquel for this
   patient.  [**Month (only) 51**] be partially secondary to emboli during procedure.  He
   will most likely need [**Female First Name (un) **]-psych placement.

   - check EKG for QTc
   - cont frequent re-orientation
   - minimize lines
   - minimize restraints
   - correct sleep wake cycles
   - OOB as much as possible
   # Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF 30-35%. Appeared fluid
   overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation
   previously.  Continues to have rales and O2 requirement but does blood
   pressure cannot tolerate further diuresis.  Fluid balance about even in
   last 24 hrs, mildly negative
   - continue 20mg torsemide daily to keep him even
   - oxygen for SaO2 > 92%, wean O2 as tolerated
   - Continue Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
   # Cellulitis:
   Left lower extremity rash with eschar above lesion.  Does not appear to
   be as inflamed currently, however will continue to treat.
   - Day 5 of cephelexin
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.

   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. s/p DES to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD.
   Chest pain free. CE stable.
   - cont aspirin 325mg
   - cont plavix
   - cont atorvastatin 80mg
   - metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
   - holding low dose acei
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
   - Continue NPH 22u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale and adjust prn
   #. EtOH abuse:
   Outside window for withdrawal. Monitor.
   - SW consult
   #. HLD:
   Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   #. HTN:
   - holding ACE Inhibitor
   -Continue Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID
   #. GERD:
   - Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   Difficult to assess in setting of delirium, but may be contributing to
   complicated mental status picture.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and hypertension (HTN). He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after presenting with hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. The patient has been diagnosed with altered mental status/delirium, acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), cellulitis, NSTEMI/CAD, DM, ethanol abuse, hyperlipidemia (HLD), HTN, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.8C (98.3F)
* Heart rate: 96 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 113/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* White blood cell count: 8.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 33.8 g/L
* Platelet count: 174 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood glucose: 136 mg/dL

The patient has multiple medical conditions, including CHF, DM, and CAD, which may be contributing to his altered mental status and delirium. He has also developed cellulitis in his left lower extremity and may require further treatment.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and altered mental status/delirium may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's CHF and CAD may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status/delirium may worsen if not properly managed, leading to neurological complications such as seizures or stroke.
5. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and other medical conditions may increase his risk of developing infections.
6. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk of bleeding.
7. Renal failure: The patient's CHF and DM may increase his risk of developing renal failure.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's altered mental status/delirium is likely secondary to his multiple medical conditions, including CHF, DM, and CAD. He will require further treatment and management to improve his mental status and reduce his risk of developing complications. The patient's cellulitis will require further treatment and management to prevent further complications. The patient's cardiac conditions will require ongoing management to prevent cardiac complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, and transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization, s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient's condition is complex, with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. The patient has a history of delirium, which has improved but still has intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C (98.3F), heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/54 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 94%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.7-5.2 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 33.8-30.7%
* Plt: 174-166 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.2-1.3 mg/dL
* TCO2: 33 mmHg
* Glucose: 136-154 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.9/29.4/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/3/0.11, ALT/AST: 29/42, Alk Phos/T Bili: 75/0.9, Amylase/Lipase: 10/10, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Altered Mental Status/Delirium: Improved, but still has intermittent hyperactive delirium
* Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: CHF with EF 30-35%, appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation previously
* Cellulitis: Left lower extremity rash with scabs above lesion, does not appear to be as inflamed currently
* NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation
* DM: Will continue NPH and insulin sliding scale from OSH
* EtOH abuse: Outside window for withdrawal, monitor
* HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* HTN: Holding ACE Inhibitor, continue Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID
* GERD: Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
* Anxiety/Depression: Difficult to assess in setting of delirium, but may be contributing to complicated mental status picture

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue seroquel qhs and qam
* Check EKG for QTc
* Cont frequent re-orientation
* Minimize lines
* Minimize restraints
* Correct sleep wake cycles
* OOB as much as possible
* Screen for Rehab
* Continue 20mg torsemide daily to keep him even
* Continue Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID as tolerated by BP
* Day 5 of cephelexin
* Continue aspirin 325mg, plavix, atorvastatin 80mg, and metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
* Holding low dose acei
* Continue NPH 22u and Humalog sliding scale and adjust prn
* Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Ranitidine 150mg PO BID

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Increased agitation and aggression
* Worsening of delirium
* Development of new lesions in the brain
* Progression of CHF
* Infection of the cellulitis
* Recurrence of NSTEMI/CAD
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia
* Hypertension or hypotension
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care as needed to prevent these complications and improve his overall outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and is currently being treated for various medical conditions.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.3C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/60 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 97% on room air, and he is receiving 100% oxygen via non-invasive ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals a well-nourished, overweight individual with a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. His peripheral pulses are diminished, and he has bilateral lower extremity edema. His skin is notable for a rash on his left leg with eschar, which appears more like venous stasis than cellulitis.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.7, hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 174 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 26 mg/dL.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Altered Mental Status/Delirium: The patient has been experiencing altered mental status and delirium since admission, which has improved with the use of seroquel.
2. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF with an ejection fraction of 30-35%, and he was previously fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation.
3. Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity rash with scabs above the lesion, which is being treated with cephelexin.
4. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient has a history of unstable angina and elevated troponin levels, and he underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.
5. DM: The patient has a history of diabetes and is being treated with NPH and insulin sliding scale.
6. EtOH Abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is being monitored for withdrawal.
7. HLD: The patient is being treated with atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.
8. HTN: The patient has a history of hypertension and is being treated with metoprolol tartrate.
9. GERD: The patient has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and is being treated with ranitidine.
10. Anxiety/Depression: The patient may be experiencing anxiety and depression, which is difficult to assess in the setting of delirium.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen, leading to increased agitation and difficulty with care.
2. Development of sepsis: The patient's cellulitis may worsen, leading to the development of sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and CHF may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's history of hypoxemic respiratory failure may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of GERD and DM may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or pancreatitis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of EtOH abuse and delirium may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.

Based on the patient's medical conditions and potential complications, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of NSTEMI and delirium. He has a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse. He was transferred from an outside hospital for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He was given DES to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD. He has been experiencing delirium, which has improved slightly with the addition of seroquel. He has also been experiencing cellulitis, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and hypertension. He has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and anticoagulants. He is currently on a regimen of seroquel, torsemide, metoprolol, and ranitidine.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen or persist, which could lead to increased agitation, confusion, and difficulty with breathing.
2. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis may worsen or spread to other areas of the body, which could lead to increased inflammation, infection, and sepsis.
3. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient's CHF may worsen, which could lead to increased fluid overload, hypoxemia, and decreased cardiac output.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of stroke, cardiac arrest, and kidney damage.
5. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of cardiac arrest, heart failure, and death.
6. DM: The patient's DM may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and coma.
7. EtOH Abuse: The patient's EtOH abuse may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of withdrawal, seizures, and death.
8. HLD: The patient's HLD may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of atherosclerosis, cardiac arrest, and death.
9. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's anxiety/depression may worsen, which could lead to increased risk of suicidal ideation, self-harm, and decreased quality of life.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's delirium and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's cellulitis with antibiotics and wound care.
3. Continue to manage the patient's CHF with diuretics and anticoagulants.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with antihypertensive medications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's NSTEMI/CAD with anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents.
6. Continue to manage the patient's DM with insulin and oral medications.
7. Continue to manage the patient's EtOH abuse with withdrawal management and counseling.
8. Continue to manage the patient's HLD with statins and lifestyle modifications.
9. Continue to manage the patient's anxiety/depression with psychotherapy and medication.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

Patient's Condition:

* The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for cardiac catheterization due to NSTEMI and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
* The patient has been agitated and delirious since admission, with intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night.
* He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli.
* The patient's cardiac condition includes acute on chronic systolic CHF, with an EF of 30-35%, and previous hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation.
* He also has cellulitis in his left lower extremity, and symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina and NSTEMI.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Delirium: The patient's delirium is a significant concern, as it can lead to increased agitation, falls, and other complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacteremia could lead to sepsis, which could further compromise his cardiac and respiratory status.
* Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac condition, including acute on chronic systolic CHF and previous hypoxemic respiratory failure, puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory status is also a concern, as he has a history of hypoxemic respiratory failure and requires oxygen therapy.
* Neurological Complications: The patient's brain lesions and potential encephalopathy could lead to neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, and cognitive decline.
* Wound Infections: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacteremia could lead to wound infections, which could further compromise his overall health.
* Renal Complications: The patient's cardiac condition and potential sepsis could lead to renal complications such as acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
* GI Complications: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and potential GI bleeding could lead to GI complications such as bleeding, perforation, and sepsis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He was also diagnosed with acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), cellulitis, and NSTEMI/CAD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Stable, with a temperature of 36.7C (98F), heart rate of 79 beats per minute, blood pressure of 111/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 12 mmHg, and his pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) is 30/20 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 750 mL of intravenous fluids and has lost 575 mL of fluid through urine output, resulting in a negative fluid balance of -80 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy at a rate of 2 L/min, and his arterial blood gas (ABG) results are within normal limits.
* Neurological status: The patient is awake and alert, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15. He has some degree of agitation, which is being managed with sedation.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is 6.9 x 10^9/L, his hemoglobin (Hb) is 10.7 g/dL, and his platelet count (PLT) is 202 x 10^9/L. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 30 mg/dL, and his creatinine (Cr) is 1.3 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's history of CHF and respiratory failure increases his risk of developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and positive blood cultures increase his risk of developing sepsis.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and CHF increases his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
* Delirium: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and chronic dementia increases his risk of developing delirium.
* Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and history of CHF increase his risk of developing pressure ulcers.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities and potential medical complications. It is essential to closely monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage these complications.
